narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A deeper introduction to Chinese vocabulary, how to read and write, as well as more intermediate grammar.
Taking this course greatly improved my Chinese vocabulary and writing and speaking skills.
CHNS 112 and 122 have been my favorite courses at Yale. I learned how to read, write, and speak Chinese. I started out knowing very few phrases, and now my vocabulary consists of 800+ characters!
In this heritage Chinese course, I focused on further improving my writing, reading, listening, and speaking skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: High engagement with classmates and professor, a wonderful learning experience, and the heritage track provides an opportunity to explore deeper into my cultural background and Asian American history.

Weaknesses: None

One strength of this class was that the teacher regularly called on us to participate in class (multiple times), so I feel like I got to know my classmates, and I was comfortable in our virtual learning environment.

Strengths: Chan Laoshi has been my favorite professor at Yale. She truly cares about every student. She wants to make sure that every student is keeping up with the material. She understands that every student is at a different level, and she adjusts her teaching accordingly!

Weaknesses: None!
I love how participatory the course is. We're all constantly practicing speaking during class, and I love all the pair work, which allowed us all to get to know each other.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Smaller class size and practice reading and writing Chinese during class were very helpful in the online format. Although I did lose some motivation to learn hanzi every day, so I often saved a lot of it for one day of the week. I liked the Fall semester's method of daily quizzes to force me to be accountable for learning 5 hanzi per day. It is unfortunately very easy to become disconnected, which can't be helped even in the best online classes.

One-on-one breakout rooms were a little awkward -- not anything objective, but I think putting 3+ people in a breakout room makes small group discussions flow better, plus we can learn from more people at once

Chan Laoshi always individually asked us questions in class, and that would be a very good way to keep us engaged with the material. When we learned a new grammar point in class, she would ask us to try using the new grammar point, so we would be able to practice with her. She also put us in breakout rooms occasionally, and this allowed us to practice our Chinese and meet new friends!
I love the pair work, because it allowed us to get to know each other even over zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I really loved my first-year experience in Yale's Chinese department. The level of engagement, feedback, and self-growth I received made this one of my favorite classes.
Yes
Yes, it has really helped me both academically in learning Chinese and emotionally in becoming proud of my heritage.

100%!! I came into this class VERY intimated because I knew very little Mandarin. However, Chan Laoshi is extremely understanding. She knows that Mandarin is a very difficult language, and she will make sure you are following along. As long as you are willing to put in the work, the course will be extremely rewarding for you!
I would 100% recommend this course to Heritage Chinese speakers at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Supplemental videos/readings
Live virtual lecture and live virtual TA session
I learned the most from virtual participation in class, with the teacher calling on students to answer questions.

Four days synchronous on Zoom, 1 day supplemental material
The supplemental material typically consisted of readings and/or videos
Virtual seminar
